item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Harnessing a Novel Organophotocatalyst for CH Functionalization and E–Z Isomerization
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A novel pyridazine‐based organophotocatalyst that enables light‐driven CH functionalization of α‐aminoalkyl naphthols and E–Z isomerization of 1,4‐enedione derivatives. This sustainable methodology offers efficient transformations under mild conditions, showcasing a green alternative to traditional protocols.
Organic chemistry continues to evolve by discovering and applying novel catalytic systems that enable efficient and selective transformations. Herein, the development and utilization of a newly synthesized organophotocatalyst for CH functionalization and isomerization reactions are reported. A pyridazine derivative is successfully used here as a photocatalyst to synthesize 1,3‐oxazines via CH functionalizations of Betti bases (α‐aminoalkyl naphthols) and for the E–Z isomerization of 2‐(alkylthio)‐substituted‐1,4‐enedione derivatives. A tentative mechanism is also proposed for the catalytic behavior of the novel photocatalyst.
item.content:encoded:
A novel pyridazine-based organophotocatalyst that enables light-driven CH functionalization of α-aminoalkyl naphthols and E–Z isomerization of 1,4-enedione derivatives. This sustainable methodology offers efficient transformations under mild conditions, showcasing a green alternative to traditional protocols.


Organic chemistry continues to evolve by discovering and applying novel catalytic systems that enable efficient and selective transformations. Herein, the development and utilization of a newly synthesized organophotocatalyst for CH functionalization and isomerization reactions are reported. A pyridazine derivative is successfully used here as a photocatalyst to synthesize 1,3-oxazines via CH functionalizations of Betti bases (α-aminoalkyl naphthols) and for the E–Z isomerization of 2-(alkylthio)-substituted-1,4-enedione derivatives. A tentative mechanism is also proposed for the catalytic behavior of the novel photocatalyst.

item.dc:title: Harnessing a Novel Organophotocatalyst for CH Functionalization and E–Z Isomerization

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Catalytic Behavior of Cobalt Complexes Bearing Imine–Pyridine–Oxazoline Ligands in Isoprene Polymerization
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
NNN‐pincer cobalt complexes are used to catalyze isoprene polymerization. Upon activation with AlEt2Cl, these cobalt complexes exhibit high catalytic activity and thermal stability in isoprene polymerization and provide cis‐1,4/3,4‐polyisoprene (cis‐1,4/3,4 ≈ 2:1).
A series of cobalt complexes bearing imine–pyridine–oxazoline ligands are successfully synthesized and characterized. Upon activation with diethylaluminum chloride (AlEt2Cl), these cobalt complexes exhibit high catalytic activity in isoprene polymerization and provide cis‐1,4‐co‐3,4 polyisoprene (cis‐1,4/3,4 ≈ 2:1). Among them, a complex featuring a diphenylmethyl substituent demonstrates the highest thermal stability, maintaining a catalytic activity of up to 1.06 × 105 g mol−1 h−1 at 70 °C. Single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction analysis shows that this complex adopts a trigonal bipyramidal configuration via N,N,N‐tridentate coordination to the cobalt center. Both the ligand architecture and the polymerization temperature are found to play critical roles in determining the catalytic performance and the structural properties of the resulting polymers. Furthermore, the influence of various polymerization parameters on catalytic activity and selectivity are systematically investigated.
item.content:encoded:
NNN-pincer cobalt complexes are used to catalyze isoprene polymerization. Upon activation with AlEt2Cl, these cobalt complexes exhibit high catalytic activity and thermal stability in isoprene polymerization and provide cis-1,4/3,4-polyisoprene (cis-1,4/3,4 ≈ 2:1).


A series of cobalt complexes bearing imine–pyridine–oxazoline ligands are successfully synthesized and characterized. Upon activation with diethylaluminum chloride (AlEt2Cl), these cobalt complexes exhibit high catalytic activity in isoprene polymerization and provide cis-1,4-co-3,4 polyisoprene (cis-1,4/3,4 ≈ 2:1). Among them, a complex featuring a diphenylmethyl substituent demonstrates the highest thermal stability, maintaining a catalytic activity of up to 1.06 × 105 g mol−1 h−1 at 70 °C. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that this complex adopts a trigonal bipyramidal configuration via N,N,N-tridentate coordination to the cobalt center. Both the ligand architecture and the polymerization temperature are found to play critical roles in determining the catalytic performance and the structural properties of the resulting polymers. Furthermore, the influence of various polymerization parameters on catalytic activity and selectivity are systematically investigated.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of the [6‐5‐5‐3] Tetracyclic Core of Cryptotrione
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Cryptotrione, a potent anticancer and structurally complex C35 terpene belonging to the cryptoquinonemethide family, has an unprecedented [6‐6‐6‐5‐5‐3] hexacyclic skeleton with a strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane core and [5‐5] spirocyclic moiety. Herein, we describe a concise approach for the synthesis of the [6‐5‐5‐3] B‐D‐E‐F tetracyclic core of cryptotrione without protecting groups. The unusual [6‐5‐5] B‐D‐E tricyclic core including a spiro all‐carbon quaternary stereocenter, found in cryptotrione as well as other cryptoquinonemethides, was efficiently constructed by a transannular aldol reaction followed by an RCM reaction. A substrate‐controlled diastereoselective cyclopropanation was employed to forge the strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexene motif with a side chain.
item.content:encoded: Cryptotrione, a potent anticancer and structurally complex C35 terpene belonging to the cryptoquinonemethide family, has an unprecedented [6-6-6-5-5-3] hexacyclic skeleton with a strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexane core and [5-5] spirocyclic moiety. Herein, we describe a concise approach for the synthesis of the [6-5-5-3] B-D-E-F tetracyclic core of cryptotrione without protecting groups. The unusual [6-5-5] B-D-E tricyclic core including a spiro all-carbon quaternary stereocenter, found in cryptotrione as well as other cryptoquinonemethides, was efficiently constructed by a transannular aldol reaction followed by an RCM reaction. A substrate-controlled diastereoselective cyclopropanation was employed to forge the strained bicyclo[3.1.0]hexene motif with a side chain.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoinduced Cascade Cyclization of ortho ‐Alkynylanilines To Access Dithiocyanated or Selenocyanated Indoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A photoinduced cyclization and dithiocyanation/selenocyanation of ortho‐alkynylanilines with NH4SCN/KSeCN provided various dithiocyanated and selenocyanated indoles. The structure of the indole framework was confirmed by single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction. In addition, a series of experiments investing scale‐up, other starting materials, and radical inhibition/capture were carried out to study the application and reaction process of this cascade system.
item.content:encoded: A photoinduced cyclization and dithiocyanation/selenocyanation of ortho-alkynylanilines with NH4SCN/KSeCN provided various dithiocyanated and selenocyanated indoles. The structure of the indole framework was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In addition, a series of experiments investing scale-up, other starting materials, and radical inhibition/capture were carried out to study the application and reaction process of this cascade system.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of 3‐Aminotetrahydrofurans and Tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]furans by Gold‐Catalyzed Cyclization of 3‐Aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A gold‐catalyzed reaction of 3‐aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols is described. 2‐Arylidene‐3‐aminotetrahydrofurans were synthesized via intramolecular nucleophilic cyclization of the hydroxy group with the activated alkyne. When the reaction was carried out with phenols as an additional nucleophile and Sc(OTf)3 as an activating reagent, tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]benzofurans were obtained. The reaction proceeded via a deaminative nucleophilic substitution of 3‐aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols with phenols, followed by a successive intramolecular cyclization of the two hydroxy groups with the activated alkyne. When 1,3‐dicarbonyl compounds were used as the nucleophile, the corresponding substituted tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b] furans were formed. To further understand the nature of this reaction, the intramolecular nucleophilic addition of alkynyl diol intermediate with gold complex were investigated as a model substrate using DFT calculations.
item.content:encoded: A gold-catalyzed reaction of 3-aminopent-4-yn-1-ols is described. 2-Arylidene-3-aminotetrahydrofurans were synthesized via intramolecular nucleophilic cyclization of the hydroxy group with the activated alkyne. When the reaction was carried out with phenols as an additional nucleophile and Sc(OTf)3 as an activating reagent, tetrahydrofuro[2,3-b]benzofurans were obtained. The reaction proceeded via a deaminative nucleophilic substitution of 3-aminopent-4-yn-1-ols with phenols, followed by a successive intramolecular cyclization of the two hydroxy groups with the activated alkyne. When 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds were used as the nucleophile, the corresponding substituted tetrahydrofuro[2,3-b] furans were formed. To further understand the nature of this reaction, the intramolecular nucleophilic addition of alkynyl diol intermediate with gold complex were investigated as a model substrate using DFT calculations.

item.dc:title: Synthesis of 3‐Aminotetrahydrofurans and Tetrahydrofuro[2,3‐b]furans by Gold‐Catalyzed Cyclization of 3‐Aminopent‐4‐yn‐1‐ols

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iodine catalysed [3+3] cycloaddition strategy for the synthesis of carbon substituted 1,4‐ piperazines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Piperazine moiety is found to be the promising core in several biologically active compounds and some of the marketed blockbuster drugs such as Glivec(imatinib) and Viagra(sildenafil).However, the substitution pattern in the piperazine ring reveals that the synthesis of carbon substituted scaffold remains a challenge without pre‐functionalized piperazine core. Herein, we are disclosing a straightforward, catalytic, one pot, metal‐free synthetic route to synthesize carbon substituted 1,4‐piperazines from easily available starting materials. This synthetic pathway is free from cautious imine synthesis and previously reported well‐articulated starting material which are leading to limited substrate scope. Our approach involves in‐situ generation of 1,3 dipoles and their [3+3] cycloaddition catalyzed by iodine in water.
item.content:encoded: Piperazine moiety is found to be the promising core in several biologically active compounds and some of the marketed blockbuster drugs such as Glivec(imatinib) and Viagra(sildenafil).However, the substitution pattern in the piperazine ring reveals that the synthesis of carbon substituted scaffold remains a challenge without pre-functionalized piperazine core. Herein, we are disclosing a straightforward, catalytic, one pot, metal-free synthetic route to synthesize carbon substituted 1,4-piperazines from easily available starting materials. This synthetic pathway is free from cautious imine synthesis and previously reported well-articulated starting material which are leading to limited substrate scope. Our approach involves in-situ generation of 1,3 dipoles and their [3+3] cycloaddition catalyzed by iodine in water.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Metal‐Free Four‐component Strategy to Access Thioether‐Derived Imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines and Imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A metal‐free construction of thioether‐derived imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines and imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles holds significant potential in medicinal chemistry. However, the exploration of multicomponent synthesis using simple chemical feedstocks has not been thoroughly investigated. A new four‐component strategy involving base‐mediated annulation and I2‐promoted sulfenylation has been developed, utilizing readily accessible α‐bromoketones, 2‐aminopyridines, and alkyl bromides, with sodium thiosulfate (Na2S2O3.5H2O) serving as the sulfur source. Consequently, this approach effectively produces a series of imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridine‐derived thioethers in moderate to good yields, showcasing a wide substrate scope with good functional group tolerance and compatibility. Furthermore, the multicomponent protocol has been successfully extended to synthesize sulfenyl‐derived imidazo[2,1‐b]thiazoles in acceptable yields using the corresponding 2‐aminothiazole. Importantly, metal‐free multicomponent reactions have been successfully employed on a gram scale in open air, and a plausible mechanism has also been proposed based on existing experimental results.
item.content:encoded: A metal-free construction of thioether-derived imidazo[1,2-a]pyridines and imidazo[2,1-b]thiazoles holds significant potential in medicinal chemistry. However, the exploration of multicomponent synthesis using simple chemical feedstocks has not been thoroughly investigated. A new four-component strategy involving base-mediated annulation and I2-promoted sulfenylation has been developed, utilizing readily accessible α-bromoketones, 2-aminopyridines, and alkyl bromides, with sodium thiosulfate (Na2S2O3.5H2O) serving as the sulfur source. Consequently, this approach effectively produces a series of imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine-derived thioethers in moderate to good yields, showcasing a wide substrate scope with good functional group tolerance and compatibility. Furthermore, the multicomponent protocol has been successfully extended to synthesize sulfenyl-derived imidazo[2,1-b]thiazoles in acceptable yields using the corresponding 2-aminothiazole. Importantly, metal-free multicomponent reactions have been successfully employed on a gram scale in open air, and a plausible mechanism has also been proposed based on existing experimental results.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Ligand‐Free Copper‐Catalyzed Allenylative C‐P Coupling of Propargylic Acetates with H‐Phosphine Oxides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The extra‐ligand‐free CuTC‐catalyzed C‐P cross‐coupling reaction of propargylic acetates with H‐phosphine oxides is reported to afford allenylphosphine oxides. The reaction took place efficiently with diphenylphosphine oxide and electron‐deficient di(4‐fluorophenyl)phosphine oxide, but less effectively with electron‐rich ones such as di(4‐methoxylphenyl)phosphine oxide and dialkylphosphine oxides. H‐phosphine oxides themselves may serve as the ligand.
item.content:encoded: The extra-ligand-free CuTC-catalyzed C-P cross-coupling reaction of propargylic acetates with H-phosphine oxides is reported to afford allenylphosphine oxides. The reaction took place efficiently with diphenylphosphine oxide and electron-deficient di(4-fluorophenyl)phosphine oxide, but less effectively with electron-rich ones such as di(4-methoxylphenyl)phosphine oxide and dialkylphosphine oxides. H-phosphine oxides themselves may serve as the ligand.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: On the Preparation of Nickel Porphyrins Bearing Two to Four Nitro Groups at β‐Positions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The preparation and unambiguous identification via NMR spectroscopy of all six β$\beta$,β‐dinitrometalloporphyrin isomers and three out of fourβ$\beta$,β,β‐trinitrometalloporphyrin isomers are described, along with attempts to prepare β,β,β,β‐tetranitrometalloporphyrins via both direct nitration and condensation of nitropyrroles.
The preparation, isolation, and identification of dinitro, trinitro, and tetranitro metalloporphyrins bearing nitro groups on pyrrole rings—desirable intermediates that enable fundamental changes in the chemico‐physical properties of the porphyrin core—are studied. All six possible dinitro‐Ni‐TPP isomers are formed; three are isolated as pure substances using column chromatography, while the remaining three are inseparable. All possible trinitro‐Ni‐TPP isomers are prepared and isolated, except for the 2,7,13 isomer. Attempts to synthesize tetranitro‐Ni‐TPP either through direct nitration of metalloporphyrin or via direct condensation of the nitropyrrole building blocks are unsuccessful. The molecular structures are unambiguously identified using 2D NMR experiments. Some experimental observations, though not all, are consistent with quantum chemical calculations performed on the geometry, energy, Fukui indices, dipole moments of nitroporphyrins, and the energy of nitration intermediates.
item.content:encoded:
The preparation and unambiguous identification via NMR spectroscopy of all six β$\beta$,β-dinitrometalloporphyrin isomers and three out of fourβ$\beta$,β,β-trinitrometalloporphyrin isomers are described, along with attempts to prepare β,β,β,β-tetranitrometalloporphyrins via both direct nitration and condensation of nitropyrroles.


The preparation, isolation, and identification of dinitro, trinitro, and tetranitro metalloporphyrins bearing nitro groups on pyrrole rings—desirable intermediates that enable fundamental changes in the chemico-physical properties of the porphyrin core—are studied. All six possible dinitro-Ni-TPP isomers are formed; three are isolated as pure substances using column chromatography, while the remaining three are inseparable. All possible trinitro-Ni-TPP isomers are prepared and isolated, except for the 2,7,13 isomer. Attempts to synthesize tetranitro-Ni-TPP either through direct nitration of metalloporphyrin or via direct condensation of the nitropyrrole building blocks are unsuccessful. The molecular structures are unambiguously identified using 2D NMR experiments. Some experimental observations, though not all, are consistent with quantum chemical calculations performed on the geometry, energy, Fukui indices, dipole moments of nitroporphyrins, and the energy of nitration intermediates.
item.dc:creator: Ameneh Tatar, Martin Havlík, Tereza Navrátilová, Tereza Uhlíková, Michaela Drozdová, Karolína Hricková, Jan Hajduch, Pavel Anzenbacher Jr., Bohumil Dolenský

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: DMAPO/Boc2O‐Mediated One‐Pot Direct N‐Acylation of Sulfoximines with Carboxylic Acids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: This report describes a general and simple method for the one‐pot direct N‐acylation of sulfoximines with carboxylic acids using our previously developed 4‐(N,N‐dimethylamino)pyridine N‐oxide (DMAPO)/di‐tert‐butyl dicarbonate (Boc2O) system. The method can be performed under mild low‐temperature reaction conditions and has a wide substrate scope. The present method is operationally simple, scalable, and practical, thus it should find wide applications in both academic and industrial laboratories.
item.content:encoded: This report describes a general and simple method for the one-pot direct N-acylation of sulfoximines with carboxylic acids using our previously developed 4-(N,N-dimethylamino)pyridine N-oxide (DMAPO)/di-tert-butyl dicarbonate (Boc2O) system. The method can be performed under mild low-temperature reaction conditions and has a wide substrate scope. The present method is operationally simple, scalable, and practical, thus it should find wide applications in both academic and industrial laboratories.

item.dc:title: DMAPO/Boc2O‐Mediated One‐Pot Direct N‐Acylation of Sulfoximines with Carboxylic Acids

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Catalytic Asymmetric Transformations of Ketenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This review has summarized the catalytic advances in asymmetric ketene transformations, including: hydrofunctionalization, difunctionalization, and [2+n]‐cycloaddition reactions by focusing on the original asymmetric catalytic models, significant breakthroughs, and advances in recent 15 years.
Ketenes are indispensable building blocks in organic synthesis due to their unique physical properties as cumulenes and distinctive spectrum of reactivity profile. Thanks to the development of versatile asymmetric catalysis models, numerous breakthroughs have been achieved in enantioselective ketene transformations. This review has examined diverse catalytic protocols in asymmetric ketene transformations, including: hydrofunctionalization, difunctionalization, and various [2+n]‐cycloaddition reactions. In each section, critical selection has been made by focusing on the original asymmetric catalytic models, significant breakthroughs, and advances in recent 15 years. This article aims to expand ketene chemistry in terms of methodology development and asymmetric catalysis, and inspire novel applications in synthetic chemistry, material science, medical chemistry, etc.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Assembly of 1,2,3‐Triazole‐Fused Polycyclic Compounds by Palladium‐Catalyzed CH Bond Activation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
1,4,5,6‐tetrahydrobenzo[c][1,2,3]triazolo[4,5‐e]azepines and 4,6‐dihydro‐1H‐benzo[5,6]oxepino[3,4‐d][1,2,3]triazoles are synthesized by palladium‐catalyzed CH bond activation. Convenient domino and one‐pot sequential methods are also developed.
A palladium‐catalyzed protocol for the synthesis of 1,2,3‐triazole‐fused heterocycles, such as 1,4,5,6‐tetrahydrobenzo[c][1,2,3]triazolo[4,5‐e]azepines and 4,6‐dihydro‐1H‐benzo[5,6]oxepino[3,4‐d][1,2,3]triazoles, is reported. The method is versatile, high yielding, and even suitable for domino and one‐pot sequential protocols, combining the copper‐catalyzed reaction of alkynes and organic azides (CuAAC) with palladium‐catalyzed CH bond activation. A plausible reaction mechanism is proposed.
item.content:encoded:
1,4,5,6-tetrahydrobenzo[c][1,2,3]triazolo[4,5-e]azepines and 4,6-dihydro-1H-benzo[5,6]oxepino[3,4-d][1,2,3]triazoles are synthesized by palladium-catalyzed CH bond activation. Convenient domino and one-pot sequential methods are also developed.


A palladium-catalyzed protocol for the synthesis of 1,2,3-triazole-fused heterocycles, such as 1,4,5,6-tetrahydrobenzo[c][1,2,3]triazolo[4,5-e]azepines and 4,6-dihydro-1H-benzo[5,6]oxepino[3,4-d][1,2,3]triazoles, is reported. The method is versatile, high yielding, and even suitable for domino and one-pot sequential protocols, combining the copper-catalyzed reaction of alkynes and organic azides (CuAAC) with palladium-catalyzed CH bond activation. A plausible reaction mechanism is proposed.
item.dc:creator: Marco Chiarini, Giancarlo Fabrizi, Yuri Gazzilli, Antonella Goggiamani, Antonia Iazzetti, Federico Marrone, Andrea Serafini, Karim Ullah
item.dc:title: Assembly of 1,2,3‐Triazole‐Fused Polycyclic Compounds by Palladium‐Catalyzed CH Bond Activation

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Towards the Synthesis of 3,3‐Difluoro Deaminated Sialic Acid (C3DFKDN)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: 2‐Keto‐3‐deoxy‐d‐glycero‐d‐galacto‐nononic acid (KDN) is a nine‐carbon monosaccharide of the sialic acid family. As a deaminated analogue of N‐acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac), KDN features a hydroxyl group at C5 instead of an amine. Although present at low levels in mammalian tissues, KDN is abundant in certain tumor cells and pathogens, making it and its processing enzymes attractive targets for understanding biological functions and developing potential therapeutics. Fluorinated carbohydrate derivatives are widely used to probe and modulate carbohydrate‐active enzymes (CAZymes). Here, we report the first total synthesis of 3,3‐difluoro KDN (C3DFKDN), a novel fluorinated sialic acid derivative and a key intermediate for designing covalent inhibitors and activity‐based probes targeting KDN‐processing enzymes. Introduction of a C3‐difluoro group prevents elimination side reactions common with monofluorinated sialic acid analogues. Two synthetic strategies were explored: (1) coupling a pyranose precursor with a difluorinated alkyne bromide followed by oxidation, and (2) incorporation of a difluoroacetate building block via a Reformatsky‐type reaction. The latter approach proved more effective, affording protected C3DFKDN in an overall yield of 3.7% over 12 steps from methyl α‐d‐mannopyranoside. This work establishes methodology for the synthesis of C3‐difluorinated sialic acids and provides a foundation for developing fluorinated probes and inhibitors of KDN‐related enzymatic pathways.
item.content:encoded: 2-Keto-3-deoxy-d-glycero-d-galacto-nononic acid (KDN) is a nine-carbon monosaccharide of the sialic acid family. As a deaminated analogue of N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac), KDN features a hydroxyl group at C5 instead of an amine. Although present at low levels in mammalian tissues, KDN is abundant in certain tumor cells and pathogens, making it and its processing enzymes attractive targets for understanding biological functions and developing potential therapeutics. Fluorinated carbohydrate derivatives are widely used to probe and modulate carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes). Here, we report the first total synthesis of 3,3-difluoro KDN (C3DFKDN), a novel fluorinated sialic acid derivative and a key intermediate for designing covalent inhibitors and activity-based probes targeting KDN-processing enzymes. Introduction of a C3-difluoro group prevents elimination side reactions common with monofluorinated sialic acid analogues. Two synthetic strategies were explored: (1) coupling a pyranose precursor with a difluorinated alkyne bromide followed by oxidation, and (2) incorporation of a difluoroacetate building block via a Reformatsky-type reaction. The latter approach proved more effective, affording protected C3DFKDN in an overall yield of 3.7% over 12 steps from methyl α-d-mannopyranoside. This work establishes methodology for the synthesis of C3-difluorinated sialic acids and provides a foundation for developing fluorinated probes and inhibitors of KDN-related enzymatic pathways.
item.dc:creator: Lemeng Chao, Tom Wennekes
item.dc:title: Towards the Synthesis of 3,3‐Difluoro Deaminated Sialic Acid (C3DFKDN)

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A New Homogeneous Catalyst for the Synthesis of 3,3′‐Bis(indolyl)methanes: Collective Synthesis of Arundine, Turbomycin B, Arsindoline A, and Tris(1H‐Indol‐3‐yl)methane*
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
3,3'‐Bis(indolyl)methanes (BIMs) are a class of heterocyclic compounds that have demonstrated remarkable biological activities, such as anticancer, antibacterial properties. In this study, an efficient synthetic approach is presented using DABCO(TfOH)2 in conjunction with hexafluoroisopropanol for the preparation of BIMs. This method represents a notable advancement in synthetic chemistry, providing an efficient and flexible approach for the production of bioactive molecules.
An environmentally friendly, cost‐effective, and efficient method for synthesizing 3,3′‐bis(indolyl)methanes (BIMs) and their derivatives is developed through an electrophilic substitution reaction of indole with various aldehydes. This reaction is catalyzed by DABCO(TfOH)2, a homogeneous catalyst with 1,1,1,3,3,3‐hexafluoroisopropanol (HFIP) serving as a solvent. The process, performed exclusively in DABCO(TfOH)2, demonstrates excellent catalytic activity, yielding high product amounts (84%–98%) and showing broad functional group compatibility, which enables the efficient synthesis of both natural alkaloids and BIM derivatives. Interestingly, natural alkaloids are successfully synthesized to enhance the diversity of the compound library. Mechanistic studies highlight a delicate balance between fluorinated solvent, catalyst, and substrate as essential for achieving nature's approach to selective cyclization in organic synthesis.

Interestingly, natural alkaloids are successfully synthesized to enhance the diversity of the compound library. Mechanistic studies highlight a delicate balance between fluorinated solvent, catalyst, and substrate as essential for achieving nature's approach to selective cyclization in organic synthesis.

item.dc:title: A New Homogeneous Catalyst for the Synthesis of 3,3′‐Bis(indolyl)methanes: Collective Synthesis of Arundine, Turbomycin B, Arsindoline A, and Tris(1H‐Indol‐3‐yl)methane*

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Copper/Bis(imine)‐Catalyzed Fluoroalkylative Thiocyanation of Unactivated Alkenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Radical addition of a fluorinated fragment and thiocyanate group at the double bond is described. The reaction is performed using copper thiocyanate as a catalyst, which promotes both radical generation and thiocyanation steps.
A method for the radical difunctionalization of nonactivated alkenes using fluorinated halides and thiocyanate anion is described. A combination of cheap copper(I) thiocyanate with a readily accessible bis(imine) ligand promoted the reaction under purple light irradiation without additional photocatalyst. The method is applicable to chloro‐ and bromodifluoroacetate, as well as to other fluorinated bromides, and tolerates a wide variety of functional groups.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: The Novel Radical‐Based Strategies for the Construction of α‐Allenols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
α‐Allenols play a vital role in organic synthesis as they can undergo a wide range of transformations for the construction of natural products and pharmaceuticals. As compared to the two‐electron transfer ionic pathway, the rapid growth of radical chemistry has provided an alternative strategy to obtain α‐allenols by single‐electron transfer under mild conditions with high efficiency and excellent selectivity.
α‐Allenols have become common advanced synthons for the synthesis of various of structures and are a frequent motif in natural products and pharmaceuticals. The special reactivity can occur due to the synergistic effect of the allene and hydroxy functional groups. Thus, many remarkable and elegant protocols have been explored through ionic pathways for the construction of α‐allenols. Recently, the rapid growth of radical chemistry has provided an alternative strategy to obtain α‐allenols through single‐electron transfer. As compared to the ionic pathway, the radical pathway has clear advantages, such as mild conditions, high efficiency, and excellent selectivity control. In this review, the most important contributions for the construction of α‐allenols are summarized via radical intermediates by categorizing them into different types of substrates. Additionally, mechanistic studies and synthetic challenges are highlighted.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Facilitating the Isolation of Polar Natural Products: Mild 1,1’‐Carbonyldiimidazole‐Enabled Method for Derivatization of Acids and Alcohols
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Many secondary metabolites containing carboxylic acid and alcohol functional groups are highly polar and can be difficult to purify and isolate from complex extracts obtained from natural sources. The conversion of these natural products to their corresponding alkyl esters/ carbonates under mild conditions can simplify their purification and isolation. However, traditional derivatization methods have often relied on toxic and/ or corrosive reagents that can also lead to byproduct formation or epimerization in some instances. In this work, 1,1′‐carbonyldiimidazole (CDI), a relatively inexpensive reagent with inherently low toxicity, is utilized to activate polar natural products containing carboxylic acids and alcohols to enable the formation of less polar species (N‐acylimidazoles and N‐acyloxymidazoles). These intermediates are readily converted into methyl esters and carbonates by treatment with methanol. It is anticipated that this rather simple and versatile derivatization method can facilitate the efficient isolation of secondary metabolites bearing polar carboxylic acid and alcohol residues.

The conversion of these natural products to their corresponding alkyl esters/ carbonates under mild conditions can simplify their purification and isolation. However, traditional derivatization methods have often relied on toxic and/ or corrosive reagents that can also lead to byproduct formation or epimerization in some instances. In this work, 1,1′-carbonyldiimidazole (CDI), a relatively inexpensive reagent with inherently low toxicity, is utilized to activate polar natural products containing carboxylic acids and alcohols to enable the formation of less polar species (N-acylimidazoles and N-acyloxymidazoles). These intermediates are readily converted into methyl esters and carbonates by treatment with methanol. It is anticipated that this rather simple and versatile derivatization method can facilitate the efficient isolation of secondary metabolites bearing polar carboxylic acid and alcohol residues.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Mechanistic Insights into the [3+2] Cycloaddition Reaction of Azomethine Ylides with Methyl Vinyl Ketone in the Triplet Excited State: A Molecular Electron Density Theory Study
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The photochemically induced [3+2] cycloaddition of azomethine ylide with methyl vinyl ketone begins with the formation of a triplet biradical intermediate INT1 via the transition state structure TST1. The formation of the final spirooxindole SOIS0 requires intersystem crossing at INT1. The reaction in the triplet state is only 589 times faster than in the ground state.
The [3+2] cycloaddition (32CA) reaction of an azomethine ylide with methyl vinyl ketone in the ground and first triplet excited states has been studied within the framework of molecular electron density theory. A density functional theory‐based reactivity analysis indicates that, while azomethine ylide behaves as a supernucleophile in both states, vinyl ketone acts as a strong electrophile. This 32CA reaction presents a very low activation energy both in the ground state, 3.40 kcal mol−1, and in the triplet state, 1.47 kcal mol−1, in the gas phase. While in the ground state, the 32CA reaction is entirely ortho regio and fully endo stereoselective, in the triplet state it is entirely ortho regioselective but only partially endo stereoselective. In the ground state, the reaction proceeds to form the spirooxindole after passing through the transition state structure, whereas in the triplet state, the reaction stops at a biradical intermediate, which requires an intersystem crossing to yield the final spirooxindole. Analysis of the kinetic parameters of the 32CA reaction in the two states in methanol indicates that in the triplet state, the reaction is only 589 times faster than in the ground state.

The formation of the final spirooxindole SOI S0 requires intersystem crossing at IN T1. The reaction in the triplet state is only 589 times faster than in the ground state.


The [3+2] cycloaddition (32CA) reaction of an azomethine ylide with methyl vinyl ketone in the ground and first triplet excited states has been studied within the framework of molecular electron density theory. A density functional theory-based reactivity analysis indicates that, while azomethine ylide behaves as a supernucleophile in both states, vinyl ketone acts as a strong electrophile. This 32CA reaction presents a very low activation energy both in the ground state, 3.40 kcal mol−1, and in the triplet state, 1.47 kcal mol−1, in the gas phase. While in the ground state, the 32CA reaction is entirely ortho regio and fully endo stereoselective, in the triplet state it is entirely ortho regioselective but only partially endo stereoselective. In the ground state, the reaction proceeds to form the spirooxindole after passing through the transition state structure, whereas in the triplet state, the reaction stops at a biradical intermediate, which requires an intersystem crossing to yield the final spirooxindole. Analysis of the kinetic parameters of the 32CA reaction in the two states in methanol indicates that in the triplet state, the reaction is only 589 times faster than in the ground state.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Total Synthesis of Pegaharmine I Enabled by Visible‐Light Photocatalytic Nitrone Formation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The total synthesis of pegaharmine I is achieved through a three‐step process, featuring a key visible‐light photocatalyzed nitrone formation reaction. Single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction confirms the structure of the natural product. Additionally, a water‐promoted photocatalytic approach is developed, highlighting the potential of visible‐light photocatalysis for the efficient synthesis of natural products.
The first total synthesis of pegaharmine I is accomplished by a three‐step strategy featuring a visible‐light‐photocatalyzed nitrone formation reaction as the key step. The structure of this natural product is confirmed by crystallographic analysis. Water‐promoted photocatalysis, achieved by incorporating water into the reaction medium, has also been established.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Gold(I)‐Catalyzed Allylation and Tandem Allylation–Cycloisomerization of Stannylated Propargyl Acetates with Allylsilanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A mild and general method for the gold(I)‐catalyzed allylation and tandem allylation–cycloisomerization of stannylated propargyl acetates with allylsilanes for the synthesis of 1,5‐enynes, with a terminal alkyne, and bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes was developed. Stannylated propargyl acetates proved useful for improving the selective formation of 1,5‐enynes and bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes. The tributylstannyl group is a transient protecting group that prevents side reactions.
Bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes, synthesized by the cycloisomerization of 1,5‐enynes, serve as key scaffolds in various natural products. Gold(I)‐catalyzed cycloisomerization of 1,5‐enynes is an efficient route to bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes. However, gold(I)‐catalyzed 1,5‐enyne synthesis, particularly with a terminal alkyne, has not yet been fully explored. This study presents a mild and general method for the gold(I)‐catalyzed allylation and tandem allylation–cycloisomerization of stannylated propargyl acetates with allylsilanes, yielding 1,5‐enynes with terminal alkyne moiety and bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes. The catalytic system ((4‐MeOC6H4)3PAuCl/AgSbF6) enabled the efficient synthesis of 1,5‐enynes with good to high yields and regioselectivities. In addition, gold(I)‐catalyzed tandem allylation–cycloisomerization using (JohnPhos)Au(MeCN)SbF6 afforded bicyclo[3.1.0]hex‐2‐enes with high regiocontrol. Stannylated propargyl acetates proved crucial in enhancing selectivity for both product classes.

Stannylated propargyl acetates proved useful for improving the selective formation of 1,5-enynes and bicyclo[3.1.0]hex-2-enes. The tributylstannyl group is a transient protecting group that prevents side reactions.

item.title: Heteroatom‐Functionalized λ5‐Phosphinines—Synthesis and Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
λ5‐Phosphinines with a S‐, P‐, N‐, and B‐substituent at the C‐4 position are synthesized by several newly developed procedures. Heteroatom‐functionalized phosphinines exhibit highly effective emission with variable and tunable wavelengths according to the substituent function. Redox, complexation, and the reaction of the functional group cause changing their fluorescence.
λ5‐Phosphinines with a heteroatom functionality at the C‐4 position are synthesized by several newly developed procedures. S‐, P‐, N‐, and B‐substituted phosphinines exhibit highly effective emission with variable and tunable wavelength according to the substituent electronic density. Photophysical properties with demonstrative examples of qualitative fluorescent detection are also reported

Redox, complexation, and the reaction of the functional group cause changing their fluorescence.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Metal–Ligand Cooperation for Iron(II)‐Catalyzed Direct Wittig‐Type Olefination from Alcohols in Air
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A one‐pot in situ alcohol oxidation–Wittig reaction in air using aphosphine‐free Fe(II) catalyst (1) bearing a redox‐active tridentate arylazo pincer was used to synthesize a broad range of substituted E olefins by dehydrogenative coupling of alcohols and phosphonium ylides. Mechanistic investigations revealed active participation of the arylazo scaffold as an electron and hydrogen reservoir in the catalytic cycle.
An iron‐catalyzed one‐pot tandem in situ oxidation–Wittig reaction is reported for the synthesis of alkenes. Using a bench‐stable Fe(II) catalyst with a redox‐noninnocent 2‐((4‐chlorophenyl)diazenyl)‐1,10‐phenanthroline ligand scaffold, a broad spectrum of substituted E olefins is synthesized in good yields by the reaction of alcohols with phosphorus ylides. Control reactions and spectroscopic studies indicate synergistic participation of the ligand, which acts as a reservoir of electrons and hydrogen, during the dehydrogenative coupling of alcohols with the phosphorus ylides.
item.content:encoded:

Mechanistic investigations revealed active participation of the arylazo scaffold as an electron and hydrogen reservoir in the catalytic cycle.


An iron-catalyzed one-pot tandem in situ oxidation–Wittig reaction is reported for the synthesis of alkenes. Using a bench-stable Fe(II) catalyst with a redox-noninnocent 2-((4-chlorophenyl)diazenyl)-1,10-phenanthroline ligand scaffold, a broad spectrum of substituted E olefins is synthesized in good yields by the reaction of alcohols with phosphorus ylides. Control reactions and spectroscopic studies indicate synergistic participation of the ligand, which acts as a reservoir of electrons and hydrogen, during the dehydrogenative coupling of alcohols with the phosphorus ylides.

item.title: Electrochemically Promoted Amination of Pyrido[2,3‐d]pyrimidin‐7‐ones: Efficient Synthesis of Palbociclib Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The pyrido[2,3‐d]‐pyrimidin‐7‐one template is a crucial molecular fragment in antineoplastic drug palbociclib. Considering the importance of pyrido[2,3‐d]‐pyrimidin‐7‐one, herein, a simple and environmentally friendly electrocatalytic amination of pyrido[2,3‐d]pyrimidin‐7‐ones is reported with N,N‐dialkyl formamides as the amine source and NaBr as the electrolyte.
The pyrido[2,3‐d]‐pyrimidin‐7‐one template is a crucial molecular fragment in antineoplastic drug palbociclib. Considering the importance of pyrido[2,3‐d]‐pyrimidin‐7‐one template, herein, a simple and environmentally friendly electrocatalytic amination of pyrido[2,3‐d]pyrimidin‐7‐ones is reported with N,N‐dialkyl formamides as the amine source and NaBr as the electrolyte. This straightforward and operationally simple protocol opens a green and efficient strategy for the synthesis of palbociclib derivatives in moderate to good yields.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Soluble Nickel–Salphen Ligand Complexes as Near‐Infrared Dyes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Five soluble nickel‐salphen‐type near‐infrared dyes are synthesized by expanding the conjugation and introducing substituent groups. After the introduction of thiophene and electron‐withdrawing terminal groups, these complexes exhibit a red shift in absorption, along with enhanced solubility in polar solvents and superior photothermal stability.
Salphen metal complexes have the advantages of simple synthesis, high stability, and excellent optical properties. However, their poor solubility, severe aggregation, and short absorption wavelengths limit their application as near‐infrared dyes. In this study, five soluble Ni–salphen complexes with strong NIR absorption are synthesized by introducing alkyl chains and extending conjugated cores. The results show that the introduction of thiophene and electron‐withdrawing end‐groups has resulted in the red‐shifted absorption of these complexes, with the absorption edge reaching 800 nm. These compounds have well solubility in organic solvents, more soluble than 8 mg mL−1 in chloroform, tetrahydrofuran, toluene, etc. The target molecules also have excellent photostability and thermal stability (Td > 325 °C).
item.content:encoded:

After the introduction of thiophene and electron-withdrawing terminal groups, these complexes exhibit a red shift in absorption, along with enhanced solubility in polar solvents and superior photothermal stability.


Salphen metal complexes have the advantages of simple synthesis, high stability, and excellent optical properties. However, their poor solubility, severe aggregation, and short absorption wavelengths limit their application as near-infrared dyes. In this study, five soluble Ni–salphen complexes with strong NIR absorption are synthesized by introducing alkyl chains and extending conjugated cores. The results show that the introduction of thiophene and electron-withdrawing end-groups has resulted in the red-shifted absorption of these complexes, with the absorption edge reaching 800 nm. These compounds have well solubility in organic solvents, more soluble than 8 mg mL−1 in chloroform, tetrahydrofuran, toluene, etc. The target molecules also have excellent photostability and thermal stability (Td > 325 °C).

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrochemical Fluorination of Proline Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This study demonstrates gem‐difluorination of challenging proline substrates using electrochemical methods, both in vessel and flow, and highlights the occurrence of characteristic by‐products and a higher conversion using a flow approach. Different thiol precursors are tested to identify key molecular features required for this reaction to occur.
The introduction of a fluorine into aliphatic substituents of lead candidates can impart unique structural characteristics that allow fine tuning of drug interactions; therefore, mild, specific, or late‐stage fluorination procedures are of growing interest in medicinal chemistry, with the potential to be applied in F‐18 radiochemistry. In this work, we demonstrate the feasibility of “reagent‐less” electrochemical fluorination leading to mono‐ and gem‐difluorinated proline cores featured in important fibroblast‐activating protein inhibitors. Our study highlights the importance of using the appropriate activator substituents for allowing the process, the impact of different reaction parameters, and characterizes the various byproducts that are generated in the reaction. We have tested the reaction using a commercially available batch system and flow apparatus, achieving maximum yields of >90% (batch) for mono‐ and of 6% (batch) and 9% (flow) for the gem‐difluorinated proline model. These proof‐of‐concept results indicate that the flow approach is more efficient, but that different activating substituents will be needed to achieve higher yields.
item.content:encoded:

Different thiol precursors are tested to identify key molecular features required for this reaction to occur.

item.title: Manganese‐Catalyzed Synthesis of Tetrahydropyridines via Borrowing Hydrogen Strategy
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Herein, a manganese‐catalyzed borrowing hydrogen cyclization of secondary alcohols with γ‐amino alcohols in a practical synthesis of 2,3,4,5‐tetrahydropyridines is reported. A wide range of different 1‐substituted ethanols and 3‐amino alcohols could undergo the homogenous manganese‐catalyzed process smoothly and furnish the corresponding products with overall moderate to good yields.
Tetrahydropyridines are versatile compounds widely used in organic synthesis and drug manufacturing. Herein, a manganese‐catalyzed borrowing hydrogen coupling of 1‐substituted ethanol derivatives with γ‐amino alcohols is reported. This novel protocol has a broad substrate scope with good functional group tolerance and affords a diverse library of valuable 2,6‐disubstituted tetrahydropyridines in moderate to good yields. Mechanistically, the reaction proceeds sequentially through catalytic dehydrogenation, dual cross‐condensation, and further hydrogenation of the formed unsaturated intermediates to yield the desired tetrahydropyridines.
item.content:encoded:
Herein, a manganese-catalyzed borrowing hydrogen cyclization of secondary alcohols with γ-amino alcohols in a practical synthesis of 2,3,4,5-tetrahydropyridines is reported. A wide range of different 1-substituted ethanols and 3-amino alcohols could undergo the homogenous manganese-catalyzed process smoothly and furnish the corresponding products with overall moderate to good yields.


Tetrahydropyridines are versatile compounds widely used in organic synthesis and drug manufacturing. Herein, a manganese-catalyzed borrowing hydrogen coupling of 1-substituted ethanol derivatives with γ-amino alcohols is reported. This novel protocol has a broad substrate scope with good functional group tolerance and affords a diverse library of valuable 2,6-disubstituted tetrahydropyridines in moderate to good yields. Mechanistically, the reaction proceeds sequentially through catalytic dehydrogenation, dual cross-condensation, and further hydrogenation of the formed unsaturated intermediates to yield the desired tetrahydropyridines.

item.dc:title: Manganese‐Catalyzed Synthesis of Tetrahydropyridines via Borrowing Hydrogen Strategy

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Total Syntheses of the Linearly‐Fused Prenylated Indole Alkaloids Asperversiamides H and M via Oxidative Rearrangement of the Putative Biosynthetic Precursor Dihydrocarneamide A
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A new synthesis of the linearly‐fused prenylated indole alkaloid dihydrocarneamide A is reported and on treatment of this with a peracid it undergoes oxidative fragmentation to give a previously unreported isomer of the natural product amoenamide A. In contrast, treatment of dihydrocarneamide A with an oxaziridine afforded a mixture of the oxindole‐containing natural products asperversiamides H and M.
An improved synthesis of the alkaloid dihydrocarneamide A is reported and this has been subjected to a biomimetic‐type oxidative rearrangement using an oxaziridine and so affording the oxidole‐containing and prenylated indole alkaloids (PIAs) asperversiamides H and M. This work serves to confirm the structure assigned to the latter. Oxidation of dihydrocarneamide A using m‐chloroperbenzoic (m‐CPBA) affords an oxidative fragmentation product representing the linear isomer of the PIA amoenamide A and thus a potential “natural product in‐waiting”. Furthermore, oxaziridine‐mediated oxidation of the epimer of dihydrocarneamide A (and the enantiomer of the structure assigned to the natural product asperversiamide F) afforded a mixture of two hitherto unreported oxindoles. Given the manner in which these last two products have been formed it seems likely that these, too, are “natural products in‐waiting”. Certain cytotoxic and antimicrobial properties of key compounds are reported.

This work serves to confirm the structure assigned to the latter. Furthermore, oxaziridine-mediated oxidation of the epimer of dihydrocarneamide A (and the enantiomer of the structure assigned to the natural product asperversiamide F) afforded a mixture of two hitherto unreported oxindoles. Given the manner in which these last two products have been formed it seems likely that these, too, are “natural products in-waiting”. item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Latent Ruthenium Complexes Supported by Two N‐Heterocyclic Carbene Ligands: Synthesis and Catalytic Activity with Distinctive Activation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Novel bis‐N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ruthenium complexes were synthesized and tested as latent olefin metathesis catalysts. Catalysts containing a diisopropylphenyl substituent on the NHC were thermally activated at relatively low temperatures compared to catalysts with mesitylene substituents. Complexes with mixed saturated/unsaturated NHCs excelled in high‐temperature reactions with challenging substrates. UV‐C light activation was successful with complexes with benzylidene ligands exclusively.
Novel bis(N‐heterocyclic carbene [NHC]) ruthenium complexes of the form (NHC1)(NHC2)Ru(=CRR')Cl2 (where NHC represents N‐heterocyclic carbene ligands and CRR’ denotes Ph‐indenylidene or benzylidene moieties) are prepared from second‐ and third‐generation Grubbs catalysts. These complexes exhibit thermal latency in ring‐closing metathesis (RCM), cross‐metathesis (CM), and several ring‐opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions. Upon UV‐C (255 nm) irradiation, two complexes that contained benzylidene ligands prove to be highly effective for the ROMP of cyclooctadiene. The most active species incorporate IPr or SIPr as at least one NHC ligand, highlighting how bulky isopropyl substituents enhance NHC lability. Beyond their utility in UV‐C‐initiated ROMP, these complexes show promising activity for high‐temperature CM and RCM of alkenyl‐nitrile substrates.
item.content:encoded:

Catalysts containing a diisopropylphenyl substituent on the NHC were thermally activated at relatively low temperatures compared to catalysts with mesitylene substituents. Complexes with mixed saturated/unsaturated NHCs excelled in high-temperature reactions with challenging substrates. UV-C light activation was successful with complexes with benzylidene ligands exclusively.


Novel bis(N-heterocyclic carbene [NHC]) ruthenium complexes of the form (NHC1)(NHC2)Ru(=CRR')Cl2 (where NHC represents N-heterocyclic carbene ligands and CRR’ denotes Ph-indenylidene or benzylidene moieties) are prepared from second- and third-generation Grubbs catalysts. These complexes exhibit thermal latency in ring-closing metathesis (RCM), cross-metathesis (CM), and several ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions. Upon UV-C (255 nm) irradiation, two complexes that contained benzylidene ligands prove to be highly effective for the ROMP of cyclooctadiene. The most active species incorporate IPr or SIPr as at least one NHC ligand, highlighting how bulky isopropyl substituents enhance NHC lability. Beyond their utility in UV-C-initiated ROMP, these complexes show promising activity for high-temperature CM and RCM of alkenyl-nitrile substrates.

item.title: N‐Heterocyclic Carbene‐Catalyzed Diastereoselective Radical Ring Opening of Bicyclobutanes to 1,1,3,3‐Tetrasubstituted Cyclobutanes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A NHC‐catalyzed radical ring opening of bicyclobutanes with readily accessible aldehydes and Togni I regents to afford 1,1,3,3‐tetrasubstituted CF3‐containing cyclobutanes is developed, which exhibits exclusive regioselectivity and up to excellent diastereoselectivity under mild conditions.
Herein, the N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC) catalyzed ring opening of bicyclo[1.1.0]butanes (BCBs) with aldehydes and Togni I reagents through a three‐component radical relay process is reported, which affords 1,1,3,3‐tetrasubstituted cyclobutanes. This reaction exhibits exclusive regioselectivity and up to excellent diastereoselectivity under mild and operating‐simple conditions. Gram‐scale synthesis and several product derivatizations demonstrate their potential utilities as versatile building blocks in synthetic chemistry.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Synthesis of 2H‐1,2‐Oxazin‐3(6H)‐One via the Cycloaddition of Nitrosobenzene with Gem‐Difluoro‐1,3‐Diene
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
An efficient method for the synthesis of 2H‐1,2‐oxazin‐3(6H)‐one via the nitroso‐Diels‐Alder reactions of nitrosobenzene with gem‐difluoro‐1,3‐dienes is developed. This strategy features good functional group tolerance, good to high yields and free of catalyst. The de‐aromatization of heterocyclic gem‐difluoroalkenes is successfully achieved by this method. The products can be converted into β‐lactam through base‐promoted rearrangement.
An efficient method for the synthesis of 2H‐1,2‐oxazin‐3(6H)‐one via the nitroso‐Diels‐Alder reaction of nitrosobenzene with gem‐difluoro‐1,3‐dienes is developed under mild conditions. This strategy features good functional group tolerance, good to high yields, and free of catalyst. The de‐aromatization of heterocyclic gem‐difluoroalkenes is successfully achieved by this method. The product can be converted into β‐lactams through base‐promoted rearrangement.

item.title: Hypodiboric Acid–Sodium Carbonate Mediated Reductive Cyclization of Nitro(Hetero)Arenes: Synthesis of Imidazopyridines, Benz(oxa/thia)zoles, Benzoxazolones, and Benzoxathiones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A hypodiboric acid–sodium carbonate‐mediated reductive cyclization of nitro(hetero)arenes has been developed for synthesizing imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines, benzoxazoles, benzothiazoles, benzoxazolones, and benzoxathiones. The reaction exhibits broad scope and functional group compatibility. Na2CO3 is essential for the reaction. Using this method, biologically active compounds like Zolimidine, Miroprofen, and Chlorzoxazone are successfully synthesized.
A hypodiboric acid–sodium carbonate‐mediated reductive cyclization of nitro(hetero)arenes has been developed for the synthesis of imidazo[1,2‐a]pyridines, benzoxazoles, benzothiazoles, benzoxazolones, and benzoxathiones. The reaction demonstrates broad scope and is compatible with a wide range of functional groups. This protocol is highly efficient, allowing nitro compounds to directly participate in the reaction. Control experiments highlight the necessity of sodium carbonate as an additive. Using this methodology, biologically active compounds such as zolimidine, miroprofen, and chlorzoxazone are successfully synthesized.

The reaction exhibits broad scope and functional group compatibility. Na2CO3 is essential for the reaction. Using this method, biologically active compounds like Zolimidine, Miroprofen, and Chlorzoxazone are successfully synthesized.

Using this methodology, biologically active compounds such as zolimidine, miroprofen, and chlorzoxazone are successfully synthesized.

item.title: Synthesis of Rhamnose‐Modified Lewis‐X‐Containing Saponins
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The synthesis of triterpenoid saponins bearing a Lewis‐X trisaccharide analogue, in which the fucose residue is replaced by a rhamnose, is presented. These saponins, designed as negative controls in dendritic cell‐specific intercellular adhesion molecule‐3‐grabbing nonintegrin‐targeted therapeutic applications, are prepared through iterative and convergent glycosylation strategies, achieving good overall yields and complete control over stereoselectivity.
The synthesis of betulinic acid and echinocystic acid saponins featuring an unnatural analogue of the Lewis‐X trisaccharide, in which the l‐fucose residue is replaced by l‐rhamnose, is reported. These triterpenoid saponins are designed as negative controls for dendritic cell‐specific intercellular adhesion molecule‐3‐grabbing nonintegrin‐targeted antiviral and immunological studies. The target saponins are synthesized using both iterative and convergent strategies, requiring nine and six steps, respectively, for the longest linear sequence starting from allyl betulinate and allyl echinocystate. Glycosylation reactions are performed using trihalogenoacetimidate and thioglycoside donors, which provide excellent yields and complete control over stereoselectivity. This work establishes a robust foundation for the synthesis of lupane‐ and oleanane‐type triterpenoid saponins incorporating Lewis‐X trisaccharide analogues.
item.content:encoded:

These saponins, designed as negative controls in dendritic cell-specific intercellular adhesion molecule-3-grabbing nonintegrin-targeted therapeutic applications, are prepared through iterative and convergent glycosylation strategies, achieving good overall yields and complete control over stereoselectivity.


The synthesis of betulinic acid and echinocystic acid saponins featuring an unnatural analogue of the Lewis-X trisaccharide, in which the l-fucose residue is replaced by l-rhamnose, is reported. These triterpenoid saponins are designed as negative controls for dendritic cell-specific intercellular adhesion molecule-3-grabbing nonintegrin-targeted antiviral and immunological studies. The target saponins are synthesized using both iterative and convergent strategies, requiring nine and six steps, respectively, for the longest linear sequence starting from allyl betulinate and allyl echinocystate. Glycosylation reactions are performed using trihalogenoacetimidate and thioglycoside donors, which provide excellent yields and complete control over stereoselectivity. This work establishes a robust foundation for the synthesis of lupane- and oleanane-type triterpenoid saponins incorporating Lewis-X trisaccharide analogues.

item.dc:description: The Front Cover visualizes the journey of bio‐based terpenes and terpenoids, from natural feedstocks to diverse chemical platforms. It highlights their structural diversity and reactivity, showcasing their potential in green chemistry, polymer science, pharmaceuticals and synthesis. The Review by J. M. Saya, R. V. A. Orru and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.202401151) offers a comprehensive guide for sustainable chemical innovation by using bio‐based terpene building blocks.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Terpenes and Terpenoids: How can we use them?
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 24, June 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The transition from petroleum‐based to renewable bio‐based chemicals has led to increased interest in terpenes and terpenoids. This overview highlights their chemistry, focusing on their reactivity and applications in polymerizations, total syntheses, pharmaceuticals, and bio‐based chemical conversions; promoting sustainable and green chemical processes.
As one of the twelve fundamental principles of green chemistry, the employed feedstocks in chemical processes received substantial attention over the past decades. These efforts can be attributed to Werpy's 2004 list of top‐value‐added chemicals from biomass. Conventional fossil‐based feedstocks are both depleting and environmentally damaging, leading to the transition towards renewable, bio‐based platform chemicals. Terpenes and terpenoids are a group of bio‐based compounds well known throughout the scientific community. Although their acquirement from natural feedstocks is well known, comprehensive overviews of their applications in synthetic chemistry remain limited. Herein, a full comprehensive overview of the reported chemistry with terpenes is provided, while specifically highlighting their reactivity. Fifteen of the most common and useful monoterpenes and terpenoids are discussed, followed by a list of the remaining known compounds belonging to this group. These fifteen compounds have been employed in a vast number of chemical transformations with different applications including: polymerizations, total syntheses, chiral reagents/auxiliaries, pharmaceuticals, and chemical conversion to other useful bio‐based chemicals. The presented chemistry in this work aims to provide chemists with a useful tool that should facilitate and stimulate the search for more sustainable, renewable, and environmentally friendly starting points for novel synthesis routes.
item.content:encoded:

This overview highlights their chemistry, focusing on their reactivity and applications in polymerizations, total syntheses, pharmaceuticals, and bio-based chemical conversions; promoting sustainable and green chemical processes.

Herein, a full comprehensive overview of the reported chemistry with terpenes is provided, while specifically highlighting their reactivity. Fifteen of the most common and useful monoterpenes and terpenoids are discussed, followed by a list of the remaining known compounds belonging to this group. These fifteen compounds have been employed in a vast number of chemical transformations with different applications including: polymerizations, total syntheses, chiral reagents/auxiliaries, pharmaceuticals, and chemical conversion to other useful bio-based chemicals. The presented chemistry in this work aims to provide chemists with a useful tool that should facilitate and stimulate the search for more sustainable, renewable, and environmentally friendly starting points for novel synthesis routes.

item.title: Rhodium‐Catalyzed (3+3) Cascade Cyclization of Diazobarbiturates with 2H‐Azirines for the Diastereoselective Construction of Spirooxazinopyrimidinediones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Under the catalysis of Rh2(esp)2 (10 mol%) and BINAP (20 mol%) in 1,2‐dichloroethane at 80 °C, a (3+3) cascade cyclization between diazobarbiturates and 2H‐azirines proceeded smoothly, yielding spirooxazinopyrimidinediones in 24‐92% yield with >20:1 diastereoselectivity. The chemical structure of one compound has been confirmed by X‐ray diffraction analysis, and the others are suggested by inference.

The chemical structure of one compound has been confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis, and the others are suggested by inference.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Fine‐Tuning Gramicidin S: How δ‐Phenylproline Affects Turns and Interaction with Membrane.
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: The introduction of a phenyl ring at the 5‐position of proline significantly impacts the conformation and membrane interactions of Gramicidin S. In this study, we investigate the effects of incorporating cis‐5‐phenyl‐L‐proline into Gramicidin S, focusing on its structural behavior and interaction with lipid bilayers. Using a homochiral model dipeptide, we demonstrate that cis‐5‐phenyl‐L‐proline induces a double γ‐turn, altering the peptide’s folding properties. This conformational bias is then translated into Gramicidin S, where the modified structure disrupts its natural amphipathic balance, leading to unfavorable interactions with membranes. Spectroscopic and biophysical analyses confirm that the modified peptide deviates from the native β‐sheet structure, likely reducing its membrane activity. These findings highlight the critical role of proline‐derived structural modifications in dictating the bioactivity of cyclic peptides and provide insight into how strategic substitutions can modulate peptide‐membrane interactions.
item.content:encoded: The introduction of a phenyl ring at the 5-position of proline significantly impacts the conformation and membrane interactions of Gramicidin S. In this study, we investigate the effects of incorporating cis-5-phenyl-L-proline into Gramicidin S, focusing on its structural behavior and interaction with lipid bilayers. Using a homochiral model dipeptide, we demonstrate that cis-5-phenyl-L-proline induces a double γ-turn, altering the peptide’s folding properties. This conformational bias is then translated into Gramicidin S, where the modified structure disrupts its natural amphipathic balance, leading to unfavorable interactions with membranes. Spectroscopic and biophysical analyses confirm that the modified peptide deviates from the native β-sheet structure, likely reducing its membrane activity. These findings highlight the critical role of proline-derived structural modifications in dictating the bioactivity of cyclic peptides and provide insight into how strategic substitutions can modulate peptide-membrane interactions.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Copper(I)‐Catalyzed Tandem One‐Pot Synthesis of Bis(1,2,3‐Triazoles) and Tetrakis (1,2,3‐Triazole) Glycoconjugates
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The work describes the copper (I)‐catalyzed convenient synthesis of 5,5′ bis‐1,2,3‐triazoles by reacting glycosyl azides with terminal alkynes using di‐tert‐butyl peroxide (DTBP) as oxidant in refluxing toluene. The reaction proceeds through intramolecular ‘click’ followed by Csp2 Csp2 bond formation in the successive steps under one‐pot conditions. The method is further explored to access tetrakis(1,2,3‐triazolyl) sialoconjugates.
The work describes the copper (I)‐catalyzed convenient synthesis of 5,5′‐bis‐1,2,3‐triazoles by reacting glycosyl azides with terminal alkynes in the presence of di‐tert‐butyl peroxide (DTBP) as oxidant in refluxing toluene. The reaction proceeds through intramolecular ‘click’ followed by Csp2Csp2 bond formation in the successive steps under one‐pot conditions. The devised protocol is further extended to access biocompatible tetrakis(1,2,3‐triazolyl) sialoconjugates under a two‐step pathway followed by Cu(I)‐catalyzed azide‐alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction. The developed glycoconjugates have been characterized using extensive spectroscopic analysis, including NMR (1H & 13C), IR, and high‐resolution mass spectrometry data, and also a single‐crystal X‐ray of compound 5e. Notably, the reaction proceeds in a one‐pot fashion with a high atom economy, where a wide substrate scope with diversity in products finally validates the importance of the devised protocol.
item.content:encoded:
The work describes the copper (I)-catalyzed convenient synthesis of 5,5′ bis-1,2,3-triazoles by reacting glycosyl azides with terminal alkynes using di-tert-butyl peroxide (DTBP) as oxidant in refluxing toluene. The reaction proceeds through intramolecular ‘click’ followed by Csp2 Csp2 bond formation in the successive steps under one-pot conditions. The method is further explored to access tetrakis(1,2,3-triazolyl) sialoconjugates.

The reaction proceeds through intramolecular ‘click’ followed by Csp2Csp2 bond formation in the successive steps under one-pot conditions. The devised protocol is further extended to access biocompatible tetrakis(1,2,3-triazolyl) sialoconjugates under a two-step pathway followed by Cu(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction. The developed glycoconjugates have been characterized using extensive spectroscopic analysis, including NMR (1H & 13C), IR, and high-resolution mass spectrometry data, and also a single-crystal X-ray of compound 5e. Notably, the reaction proceeds in a one-pot fashion with a high atom economy, where a wide substrate scope with diversity in products finally validates the importance of the devised protocol.

item.dc:title: Copper(I)‐Catalyzed Tandem One‐Pot Synthesis of Bis(1,2,3‐Triazoles) and Tetrakis (1,2,3‐Triazole) Glycoconjugates

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Alkylated 1‐Aryl‐4,5‐Dimethylimidazolium‐Based Tunable Aryl Alkyl Ionic Liquids (TAAILs)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
New tunable aryl alkyl ionic liquids based on 2‐alkyl‐1‐aryl‐4,5‐dimethylimidazoles are synthesized using a deprotonation protocol to directly modify imidazoles without the need to rebuild the heterocyclic core. The viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability of the ionic liquids are measured.
Imidazolium‐based ionic liquids are one of the most important classes of ionic liquids due to their low viscosity and multitude of possible modifications. The properties of imidazolium‐based ionic liquids are strongly influenced by their hydrogen bond interactions, especially due to the hydrogen atoms at the core of the imidazolium cation. Herein, a new class of tunable aryl alkyl ionic liquids based on 2‐alkyl‐1‐aryl‐4,5‐dimethylimidazoles is presented, which do not possess hydrogen atoms directly bound to the imidazolium core. They are synthesized by deprotonation of the corresponding imidazoles, avoiding the need to rebuild the imidazolium motif. Electron donating substituents at the aryl ring allow for the deprotonation at the C2‐position of the imidazole ring. All ionic liquids are fully characterized (1H, 13C, 19F‐NMR, EA) and their physical properties, including their viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability, are examined.
item.content:encoded:

The viscosity, conductivity, and electrochemical stability of the ionic liquids are measured.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A Chiron Approach to the Practical and Scalable Synthesis of the β₃‐Adrenergic Receptor Agonist Vibegron
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: A practical and scalable synthesis of the β3‐adrenergic receptor agonist Vibegron has been developed using a streamlined chiral‐pool approach from readily available 4‐nitro‐D‐phenylalanine and (R)‐mandelic acid. The synthesis features a key acid‐catalyzed N‐acyl iminium ion cyclization followed by a highly diastereoselective reduction, enabling efficient construction of the cis‐2,5‐disubstituted pyrrolidine core. Final amidation with a commercially available pyrrolopyrimidine sodium salt furnished Vibegron in excellent overall yield.
item.content:encoded: A practical and scalable synthesis of the β3-adrenergic receptor agonist Vibegron has been developed using a streamlined chiral-pool approach from readily available 4-nitro-D-phenylalanine and (R)-mandelic acid. The synthesis features a key acid-catalyzed N-acyl iminium ion cyclization followed by a highly diastereoselective reduction, enabling efficient construction of the cis-2,5-disubstituted pyrrolidine core. Final amidation with a commercially available pyrrolopyrimidine sodium salt furnished Vibegron in excellent overall yield.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Introduction of Structural Diversity at the C2 Position of Unsaturated Iminosugars through Palladium‐Catalysed Cross‐Coupling Reactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: To vary the functionality of iminosugars at the C2 position, protected 2‐iodoiminoglycals in the D‐gluco, D‐galacto and D‐xylo series were efficiently synthesized from sugar lactams. Their mild palladium‐catalyzed aminocarbonylation, arylation and phosphonylation were successful and provided a range of C2‐functionalized iminoglycals in good yields. Two of these compounds were O‐deprotected to afford 1,2‐unsaturated iminosugars that proved to be modest inhibitors of glycosidases.
item.content:encoded: To vary the functionality of iminosugars at the C2 position, protected 2-iodoiminoglycals in the D-gluco, D-galacto and D-xylo series were efficiently synthesized from sugar lactams. Their mild palladium-catalyzed aminocarbonylation, arylation and phosphonylation were successful and provided a range of C2-functionalized iminoglycals in good yields. Two of these compounds were O-deprotected to afford 1,2-unsaturated iminosugars that proved to be modest inhibitors of glycosidases.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Fluorinated Aminophosphonates and Aminophosphonic Acids: A Journey Through Recent Advances
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: This review aims to summarise the most recent developments in the chemistry of fluorinated aminophosphonates and aminophosphonic acids, with a particular focus on literature published since the turn of 2016/2017. Fluorinated derivatives of aminophosphonates and aminophosphonic acids represent a rapidly growing area of interest due to their unique chemical properties and potential applications in various fields, including medicinal and agricultural chemistry. In this work, special emphasis is placed on highlighting the most significant reports concerning selective and efficient synthetic methodologies for these compounds. Particular attention is given to strategies that offer high yields, regio‐ or stereoselectivity, and operational simplicity, including direct fluorination, addition reactions, as well as catalytic and radical processes. Additionally, the review discusses the potential practical applications of these fluorinated derivatives, such as their roles as enzyme inhibitors, bioisosteres of amino acids, and potential pharmaceuticals.
