item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Ring‐Rearrangement‐Driven Formal (3+2) Cycloaddition of Enaminone‐Based Thioalkynes with Nitriles to Form Thiazole‐Containing Bis‐heterocycles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Herein, we report a one‐pot synthesis of 3,4‐dihydropyridin‐2(H)‐one containing thiazole derivatives by Bronsted acid‐mediated ring‐rearrangement and formal (3+2) cycloaddition reaction of enaminone‐based thioalkyne with alkyl/aryl nitrile. The developed protocol demonstrates a wide substrate scope for both the reacting partners with high atom‐economy furnishing very high to excellent yields of pharmaceutically relevant bis‐heterocyclic derivatives. Based on outcome of the product and control experiments, a plausible reaction mechanism has also been proposed. The gram‐scale synthesis and further synthetic transformation demonstrate the synthetic efficacy and utility of the developed protocol.

The developed protocol demonstrates a wide substrate scope for both the reacting partners with high atom-economy furnishing very high to excellent yields of pharmaceutically relevant bis-heterocyclic derivatives. Based on outcome of the product and control experiments, a plausible reaction mechanism has also been proposed. The gram-scale synthesis and further synthetic transformation demonstrate the synthetic efficacy and utility of the developed protocol.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in the Formation and Transformation of Propargyl Radical
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Propargyl radical is one of the important intermediates in organic synthesis due to its rich and diverse reactivity. In this review, the reactions involving propargyl radicals in recent years are summarized according to the means of producing propargyl radicals, reaction types, and asymmetric catalytic transformations.
Propargyl radical is a very important free radical in organic synthesis. The tautomerization with the allenyl radical enables the diverse reactivities, and then, propargyl compounds and allenes can be obtained. Because of its properties, how to control the chemical selectivity and enantioselectivity is the key in the radical propargyl functionalization. In this review, the reactions involving propargyl radicals in recent years are summarized according to the means for the production of propargyl radicals, different reaction types, and asymmetric catalytic transformations.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: N‐Heterocyclic Carbene‐Catalyzed Asymmetric Cyclization of Cyclohexadienone‐Tethered Ynals to Stereodivergent 6,5‐Bicyclic and 6,5,5‐Tricyclic Products
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A single chiral N‐heterocyclic carbene catalyst enables the transformation of prochiral cyclohexadienone‐tethered ynals into stereodivergent 6,5‐bicyclic and 6,5,5‐tricyclic products. A proposed kinetic resolution process probably enhances the enantioselectivity in the formation of bicyclic products.
Transforming a prochiral substrate into two stereodivergent products using a single chiral catalyst remains a significant challenge. Herein, an NHC‐catalyzed asymmetric cyclization of cyclohexadienone‐tethered ynals, enabling the preparation of two stereodivergent products: 6,5‐bicyclic and 6,5,5‐tricyclic frameworks, is reported. The reaction proceeds through two distinct pathways: an allenolate‐Michael addition/esterification sequence and an allenolate‐Michael addition/intramolecular Dieckmann condensation process. This approach represents a novel and efficient strategy for transforming a prochiral substrate into two products in a stereodivergent manner.
item.content:encoded:
A single chiral N-heterocyclic carbene catalyst enables the transformation of prochiral cyclohexadienone-tethered ynals into stereodivergent 6,5-bicyclic and 6,5,5-tricyclic products. A proposed kinetic resolution process probably enhances the enantioselectivity in the formation of bicyclic products.

The reaction proceeds through two distinct pathways: an allenolate-Michael addition/esterification sequence and an allenolate-Michael addition/intramolecular Dieckmann condensation process. This approach represents a novel and efficient strategy for transforming a prochiral substrate into two products in a stereodivergent manner.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Diazo Compounds Under Visible Light: Stereoselective Synthesis of Cyclic Architectures
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Reactions of diazo compounds under photochemical conditions find high selectivity. In the presence of light, diazo substrates can act as carbene precursors or radical sources depending upon the reaction conditions and catalysts used. This review focuses on recent advances (2020–2024) in stereoselective synthesis of various cyclic scaffolds via visible‐light irradiation of diazo compounds.
Diazo compounds are versatile and valuable reagents in organic synthesis. The reaction of diazo substrates under photochemical conditions find high selectivity compared to that under thermal conditions. In the presence of light, they can act as carbene precursors or radical sources depending upon the reaction conditions and catalysts used. Recent years have witnessed a great advancement in visible‐light‐induced photochemistry of diazo compounds for asymmetric access to various cyclic compounds. In this review, recent advances (2020–2024) in stereoselective synthesis of cyclic scaffolds via visible‐light irradiation of diazo compounds are summarized. This review is organized according to the ring size of the synthesized compounds, viz., three, four, five, six, seven, and higher‐ membered ring systems. With an emphasis of mechanistic insights and scope of the reactions, this review shades light on current trends in this emerging field.

This review focuses on recent advances (2020–2024) in stereoselective synthesis of various cyclic scaffolds via visible-light irradiation of diazo compounds.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Brønsted Acid‐Promoted Tandem Cyclization/Addition of Enaminones with H‐Phosphine Oxides for Synthesis of C2‐Phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐Chromones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones is discovered via Brønsted acid‐promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H‐phosphine oxides. Various C2‐phosphorylated products 3 and 4 are smoothly constructed in excellent yields, providing a novel strategy for C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones.
A facile and efficient protocol to synthesize C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones is discovered via Brønsted acid‐promoted tandem addition/cyclization of enaminones with H‐phosphine oxides. The reaction exhibits a broad scope, good functional group tolerance, and good yields, and features ability of a gram‐scaled synthesis. Results of mechanistic study reveal that the reaction initially undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form chromone 5, which can subsequently be reacted with 2a to yield C2‐phosphorylated 2,3‐2H‐chromones through intermolecular addition.

Various C2-phosphorylated products 3 and 4 are smoothly constructed in excellent yields, providing a novel strategy for C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones.

Results of mechanistic study reveal that the reaction initially undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form chromone 5, which can subsequently be reacted with 2a to yield C2-phosphorylated 2,3-2H-chromones through intermolecular addition.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Unlocking Indazole Synthesis from α‐Diazo‐β‐Ketoesters via Aryne Trapping: A Streamlined Approach
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
To address the growing demand to develop, beyond laboratory scale, more efficient, safer and ecofriendly, as well as scalable mechanochemical transformations, the direct synthesis of 1‐acyl‐1H‐indazoles via α‐diazo‐β‐ketoesters aryne trapping is reported. The results reveal the unexpected formation of N‐aryl‐1H‐indazoles and aryl benzoates, likely facilitated by a thia‐fries rearrangement. Density functional theory calculations elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the various reaction products.
Indazoles are high‐value chemical building blocks used in medicinal chemistry and materials science for their distinct structural and functional features. This study details a [3 + 2]‐cycloaddition reaction between various aryl‐ketodiazoesters and ortho‐(trimethylsilyl)aryl triflates under mild conditions, leading predominantly to 1‐acyl‐1H‐indazoles. N‐aryl‐1H‐indazoles and aryl benzoates are also observed as other products. The reaction exhibits broad functional group tolerance and scalability, making it a valuable synthetic approach. Mechanistic insights, derived from control experiments and density functional theory calculations, elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the products. Collectively, these findings underscore the method's potential for synthesizing complex indazole derivatives, which hold significant promises for applications in pharmaceutical development and advanced materials research.
item.content:encoded:
To address the growing demand to develop, beyond laboratory scale, more efficient, safer and ecofriendly, as well as scalable mechanochemical transformations, the direct synthesis of 1-acyl-1H-indazoles via α-diazo-β-ketoesters aryne trapping is reported. The results reveal the unexpected formation of N-aryl-1H-indazoles and aryl benzoates, likely facilitated by a thia-fries rearrangement. Density functional theory calculations elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the various reaction products.

Mechanistic insights, derived from control experiments and density functional theory calculations, elucidate the cycloaddition pathway and rationalize the formation of the products. Collectively, these findings underscore the method's potential for synthesizing complex indazole derivatives, which hold significant promises for applications in pharmaceutical development and advanced materials research.

item.title: Harnessing Electricity in Dehydrogenative Coupling: Transition Metal‐Free Synthesis of Quinoline Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Providing easy access to quinoline derivatives under room temperature, transition metal‐free, and oxidant‐free conditions using electricity as an oxidant through a dehydrogenative pathway. A wide range of functional groups are tolerated, giving the desired quinoline product in good yields.
An efficient strategy is demonstrated for the electrocatalytic synthesis of 2‐aryl quinoline derivatives via an anodic dehydrogenation of 2‐aminobenzyl alcohol molecules followed by condensation with carbonyl compounds at room temperature. The current protocol requires only electricity as the green oxidant, provides the desired products in good to excellent yield, and is compatible with a wide range of functional groups.

Providing easy access to quinoline derivatives under room temperature, transition metal-free, and oxidant-free conditions using electricity as an oxidant through a dehydrogenative pathway. A wide range of functional groups are tolerated, giving the desired quinoline product in good yields.


An efficient strategy is demonstrated for the electrocatalytic synthesis of 2-aryl quinoline derivatives via an anodic dehydrogenation of 2-aminobenzyl alcohol molecules followed by condensation with carbonyl compounds at room temperature. The current protocol requires only electricity as the green oxidant, provides the desired products in good to excellent yield, and is compatible with a wide range of functional groups.
item.dc:creator: Vageesh M., Abhijeet Anand, Subir Panja, Raju Dey
item.dc:title: Harnessing Electricity in Dehydrogenative Coupling: Transition Metal‐Free Synthesis of Quinoline Derivatives

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoredox‐Catalyzed Selective Dioxygenation of gem‐Difluorocyclopropanes to Generate α,α‐Difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: gem‐Difluorocyclopropanes are valuable synthetic intermediates in organofluorine chemistry; however, their reactivity often involves intermediates prone to fluorine elimination, leading to monofluorinated products. Here, we present a photoredox‐catalyzed dioxygenation of gem‐difluorocyclopropanes with alcohols, which retains both fluorine atoms and yields α,α‐difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers. This method is operationally simple, employs inexpensive and standard reagents, and demonstrates broad functional group tolerance. The reaction is scalable, enabling the use of the gem‐difluorocyclopropane motif as a masked precursor for α,α‐difluorinated‐1,3‐diethers in synthetic sequences. Preliminary mechanistic studies suggest a radical‐mediated process involving concerted SN2‐like ring‐opening functionalization.

The reaction is scalable, enabling the use of the gem-difluorocyclopropane motif as a masked precursor for α,α-difluorinated-1,3-diethers in synthetic sequences. Preliminary mechanistic studies suggest a radical-mediated process involving concerted SN2-like ring-opening functionalization.
